text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 5.1.19, Field Collecting Procedures, Collection Statute

IRM 5.1.19.1.1, Background: Added link to IRM 5.1.5.18, Collection Actions on Cases with Restitution-Based Assessments (RBA), to provide CSED guidance on new limited period of enforceability for speciﬁc RBAs.
) IRM
, Background: Added link to IRM
, Collection Actions on Cases with Restitution-Based Assessments (RBA), to provide CSED guidance on new limited period of enforceability for speciﬁc RBAs. (

IRM 5.1.19.1.7, Related Resources: Added additional
IRM 5.1.19.5.3, Documenting Imminent CSEDs: Removed the managerial notiﬁcation requirement to territory manager and updated section.
This supersedes IRM 5.1.19, dated April 26, 2018.
SB/SE Employees in Field Collection, Specialty Collection - Offers, Liens and Advisory, and Specialty Collection Insolvency
Table of Contents
Expiration

) This chapter will provide an overview of actions that suspend or extend the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) as well as guidance for working imminent CSED cases. While many topics are touched upon in this chapter, comprehensive guidance about all of them cannot be included here. As you use this chapter, remain alert for references to other resources, such as related IRMs and websites and access that guidance as needed to ensure a thorough understanding of CSED topics. (
) Audience. The procedures and guidance apply to SB/SE employees in Field Collection, Civil Enforcement Advice & Support Operations (CEASO), and Specialty Collection Insolvency. (
) Policy Owner. The Director, Collection Policy (
) Program Owner. SB/SE Collection Policy (
) Primary Stakeholders. The primary stakeholders that are impacted by this include: • Field Collection • CEASO • Specialty Collection - Insolvency (

) Program Goal. By following the direction within this IRM section, the will be able to: • identify transaction codes that affect the CSED • identify case actions that can suspend and or extend the CSED • identify an imminent CSED • identify what case actions that can suspend and or extend the CSED (
) Each tax assessment has a Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED). Internal Revenue Code section
provides that the length of the period collection after assessment of a tax liability is
years. The collection expiration ends the government’s right to pursue collection of a liability. (
) Prior to its amendment by the Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA section

(a) of the Internal Revenue Code authorized the Secretary to accept waivers extending the statute of limitations on collection after assess- ment prior to the expiration of the collection period. The Code did not place any restrictions on the length of the extension, the number of times an extension could be granted or the circumstances under which an extension could be obtained. RRA
signiﬁcantly revised the law regarding CSED waivers. Extensions in effect on December
, as well as requests for extensions made on or before December
, that resulted in being in effect, are subject to the following: If Then The waiver was secured “in con- The period for collection expires

5.1 Field Collecting If Then The waiver was not obtained at The period for collection expires the same time as an installment not later than December 31, agreement 2002, or the end of the original collection statute, whichever is later.
On or after January 1, 2000, waivers of the collection period must be in and are secured only when the extension is agreed to:
At the same time a partial payment installment agreement is made, when appropriate (see IRM
, Waiver Procedures for Partial Payment Installment Agreements Prior to a release of levy under IRC

that occurs after the expiration of the statutory Ten-Year period for collection. The collection statute of limitations is suspended for the period agreed to in writing. If the extension (waiver) is in connection with a partial payment installment agreement, then the suspension lasts for an additional
days after the period agreed to in writing.
in writing. If the extension (waiver) is in connection with a partial installment agreement, then the suspension lasts for an additional

days after the period agreed to in writing. Collection Statute Date Review: a. Be aware of CSEDs on accounts you are responsible for and take priate case actions to protect the CSED. b. Ensuring an accurate CSED is important to collecting the correct due and observing taxpayer rights. c. The CSED reﬂected on ICS and IDRS may not always be correct because, at times, actions that suspend or extend the CSED occur taneously, increasing the complexity of computing the CSED and requiring manual recalculation. Note: There is an exception to the ten-year CSED where restitution is ordered solely as a condition of the taxpayer’s probation or super- vised release. The Service can only administratively collect an amount of restitution ordered solely as a condition of either probation or supervised release during the actual period of either probation or supervised release, regardless of the general
-year collection period. Field Collection employees are to contact the assigned advisor for guidance on these RBA cases with limited periods of enforceability issues. See IRM

, Collection Actions on Cases with Restitution-Based Assessments (RBA), for guidance. d. If you encounter an erroneous CSED while working your case, manually calculate the correct date and receive group manager approval prior to updating it on ICS and IDRS. e. Document the case history with how you manually calculated the CSED which should include the CSED suspending events, days sus- pended/extended, with your conclusion prior to submitting the update to the group manager for approval. The group manager should be able to easily follow the calculation while they review the CSED computation for accuracy and approval of the updated CSED.
a. Be aware of CSEDs on accounts you are responsible for and take appro

priate case actions to protect the CSED. b. Ensuring an accurate CSED is important to collecting the correct amount due and observing taxpayer rights. c. The CSED reﬂected on ICS and IDRS may not always be correct because, at times, actions that suspend or extend the CSED occur simul
taneously, increasing the complexity of computing the CSED and requiring manual recalculation.

There is an exception to the ten-year CSED where restitution is ordered solely as a condition of the taxpayer’s probation or super- vised release. The Service can only administratively collect an amount of restitution ordered solely as a condition of either probation or supervised release during the actual period of either probation or supervised release, regardless of the general
-year collection period. Field Collection employees are to contact the assigned advisor for guidance on these RBA cases with limited periods of enforceability issues. See IRM
, Collection Actions on Cases with Restitution-Based Assessments (RBA), for guidance.

If you encounter an erroneous CSED while working your case, manually calculate the correct date and receive group manager approval prior to updating it on ICS and IDRS. Document the case history with how you manually calculated the CSED which should include the CSED suspending events, days sus

pended/extended, with your conclusion prior to submitting the update to the group manager for approval. The group manager should be able to easily follow the calculation while they review the CSED computation for accuracy and approval of the updated CSED.
f. Determine if the CSED reﬂected on IDRS is for an assessment that satisﬁed but there is later additional assessment(s) on the tax so, this is not an erroneous CSED. • Do not request TC
to change the CSED to the date for a later satisﬁed assessment. • Do update the ICS CSED to the current CSED for a later assessment. (

) The Director, Collection Policy is the executive responsible for the policies procedures in this IRM. (
) Field Management is responsible for ensuring that employees comply guidance and procedures described in this IRM. (
) Program Reports: • National Quality Review System (NQRS) • Integrated Collection System (ICS) • Automated Insolvency System (AIS) • ENTITY Reports (

) Program Effectiveness. The program effectiveness is measured by the following review type and by level of management: • Case reviews are conducted by Field Group Managers and under the Embedded Quality Review System (EQRS) to ensure ance with this IRM • Field Territory Managers and Field Area Directors annually program delivery and conformance to administrative and requirements • Headquarter Policy Analysts annually evaluate program delivery conformance to administrative and compliance requirements. (
) The Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) provides the transaction (TC), deﬁnition, and calendar input date that determines the Collection Expiration Date (CSED). (
) The Integrated Collection System (ICS) provides a report that identiﬁes accounts for which the CSED will expire within the next
months. (
) ENTITY is the workload management system used by collection extract and organize information about case activity and casework quality ICS. (
) The Automated Insolvency System (AIS) provides a report that is used to identify non-debtor spouses where the collection statute will expire within years.
Do not request TC
to change the CSED to the date for a later un- satisﬁed assessment. Do update the ICS CSED to the current CSED for a later unsatisﬁed assessment.

) Program Effectiveness. The program effectiveness is measured by the following review type and by level of management: • Case reviews are conducted by Field Group Managers and recorded under the Embedded Quality Review System (EQRS) to ensure compli- ance with this IRM • Field Territory Managers and Field Area Directors annually evaluate program delivery and conformance to administrative and compliance requirements • Headquarter Policy Analysts annually evaluate program delivery and conformance to administrative and compliance requirements. (
) The Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) provides the transaction coding (TC), deﬁnition, and calendar input date that determines the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED). (
) The Integrated Collection System (ICS) provides a report that identiﬁes accounts for which the CSED will expire within the next
months. (
) ENTITY is the workload management system used by collection managers to extract and organize information about case activity and casework quality from ICS. (
) The Automated Insolvency System (AIS) provides a report that is used to identify non-debtor spouses where the collection statute will expire within two years.
Program Effectiveness. The program effectiveness is measured by the following review type and by level of management:

Integrated Collection System (ICS) provides a report that for which the CSED will expire within the next 12 months.

) A variety of laws affect CSEDs. A brief summary of some of the various case actions that can suspend and/or extend a CSED follows. This IRM provides a brief overview of some of these case actions; it is not all inclusive. The following sections are included to highlight relevant issues. Details pertaining to the speciﬁc subject matter should be further researched in the applicable IRM section, which in most cases will be cross-referenced. Note: There is an exception to the ten-year CSED where restitution is ordered solely as a condition of the taxpayer’s probation or supervised release. The Service can only administratively collect an amount of restitution ordered solely as a condition of either probation or supervised release during the actual period of either probation or supervised release, regardless of the general
-year collection period. Field Collection employees are to contact the assigned advisor for guidance on these RBA cases with limited periods of enforceability issues. See IRM
, Collection Actions on Cases with Restitution-Based Assessments (RBA), for guidance. (
) More than one case action can suspend the running of the collection statute at the same time. Overlapping suspensions run concurrently; they are not cumu- lative.

) A variety of laws affect CSEDs. A brief summary of some of the various case actions that can suspend and/or extend a CSED follows. This IRM provides a brief overview of some of these case actions; it is not all inclusive. The following sections are included to highlight relevant issues. Details pertaining to the speciﬁc subject matter should be further researched in the applicable IRM section, which in most cases will be cross-referenced.
(02-07-2020) Case Actions That Can Suspend And/Or Extend A CSED

There is an exception to the ten-year CSED where restitution is ordered solely as a condition of the taxpayer’s probation or supervised release. The Service can only administratively collect an amount of restitution ordered solely as a condition of either probation or supervised release during the actual period of either probation or supervised release, regardless of the general
-year collection period. Field Collection employees are to contact the assigned advisor for guidance on these RBA cases with limited periods of enforceability issues. See IRM
, Collection Actions on Cases with Restitution-Based Assessments (RBA), for guidance.

taxes for the period ending
The tax assessment date is
which established the original CSED as
Smith is in the Army Reserves, he gets called up for combat duty and enters the combat zone on
He subse- quently leaves the combat zone on
He submits an offer in compromise on
, it is rejected on
and the rejection is not appealed.

Both case actions, entering the combat zone and submitting the offer in compro- mise, suspend and extend the CSED. The combat zone duty suspends the CSED from 05/10/2004 through 03/01/2005 plus 180 days (through 08/28/2005). ation of the offer in compromise suspends the CSED from 04/20/2005 through 10/ 17/2005 plus an additional 30 days for the rejection appeal period to 11/16/2005.

However, because these case actions overlap, the CSED will be suspended only from the date Smith enters the combat zone (TC 500 cc 56 on 05/10/2004) through the date the offer in compromise is rejected and the rejection appeal period ends (TC 481 on 11/16/2005). In this case the overlapping of the two case actions, from 04/20/2005 to 08/28/2005, is considered in the CSED extension only once.
The CSED will be extended 555 days from the original CSED of 06/01/2009. The new CSED will be 12/08/2010.

) The period of limitations on collection after assessment is suspended while taxpayer is outside the United States if the absence is for a continuous of at least six months per IRC

) To make certain that the Government has an opportunity to collect the tax the taxpayer’s return, the period does not expire (where the taxpayer has out of the country for six months or more) before a minimum of six months after the taxpayer’s return to the country. As the application of this provision can result in the CSED being suspended for a very long time, policies for the administration of this code section are now established.
page (

) These instructions are designed to promote procedural consistency in International cases and to make statute suspension procedures, applying to Domestic and International taxpayers, more comparable. They apply to Internal taxpayers who are presently abroad as well as to taxpayers who are (IRC) in the U.S., but who were abroad for at least six consecutive months after tax assessment date. (

) The period that the CSED is recalculated and updated will be more limited respect to taxpayers who have cooperated with IRS to resolve their liabilities with whom we have maximized the IRS’s ability to collect. (

) A taxpayer will be considered ″cooperative″ if the IRS determined that the taxpayer has fully responded to the IRS and has provided full information to the IRS with respect to collection of the assessment. In such instances, the case may be resolved by a taxpayer entering into a formal installment agreement or a valid offer in compromise or with the case being closed as currently-not-collectible for hardship reasons with closing codes
through (

) This policy does not apply to international taxpayers who have not resolved their liabilities and who are not cooperative. In those situations, where a taxpayer has been uncooperative or has not resolved the liability, the CSED will be recalculated and updated for the maximum amount of time allowed IRC

(c) if the IRS determines that there is signiﬁcant collection a. With respect to taxpayers who are currently outside the United States, and who have systemically loaded or manually monitored installment agreements or periodic payment offers in compromise or periodic payment offers in compromise, for which the payment schedule is up
months, the maximum length of CSED recalculation is
years the date of assessment. b. Continuous levies for taxpayers with international addresses will be culated and updated for however many years the IRC

(c) allows if the taxpayers involved have not cooperated with IRS to their liabilities. c. For taxpayers with signiﬁcant collection potential that have been out of the United States for a lengthy period of time, recalculate the CSED as necessary for the time anticipated to collect the liability up to the maximum time allowed under IRC

(c). Assets located outside the United States can count as signiﬁcant collection potential. Although assets located outside the jurisdiction of the United States cannot be levied or seized, other collection tools may be available to reach See IRM

, Collection Tools for International Cases. Example: Assets located in a country with which the U.S. has a mutual collection agreement may be seized or levied by the mutual collection country. d. International taxpayers who are being reported as currently-not- collectible with the following closing codes: •
(unable to locate), •

(unable to contact) may be subject to ongoing recalculations and updates. Again, a nation of signiﬁcant collection potential should be made when determining how long the collection statute should be recalculated. (

5.1 Field Collecting Procedures

) If the taxpayer later ﬁles their own “original” return showing a tax liability smaller than the assessed liability, and that return is accepted by the Service as ﬁled, the deﬁciency assessment should be abated to show the amount of tax reﬂected on the taxpayer’s return. The original CSED date remains intact. (
) If the taxpayer’s “original” return reﬂects more tax than that assessed from the notice of deﬁciency based on the section

(b) return, then an additional assessment is input for the increased amount. In this scenario, the original CSED remains intact and a second CSED will be systemically established based on the additional assessment.
5.1.19.3.14 (04-26-2018) Enforcement Of The Two-Tier Tax Scheme

If the taxpayer later ﬁles their own “original” return showing a tax liability smaller than the assessed liability, and that return is accepted by the Service as ﬁled, the deﬁciency assessment should be abated to show the amount of tax reﬂected on the taxpayer’s return. The original CSED date remains intact.
If the taxpayer’s “original” return reﬂects more tax than that assessed from the notice of deﬁciency based on the section

(b) return, then an additional assessment is input for the increased amount. In this scenario, the original CSED remains intact and a second CSED will be systemically established based on the additional assessment.
Reminder: The CSED reﬂected on IDRS or ICS may not be correct due to simulta- neous actions suspending or extending the CSED.

Do not solicit voluntary payments on accounts barred by statute. If a makes a payment on an account barred by statute, inform them that the payment is not required and ask if they wish to make the payment or have it returned to them. The taxpayer must be advised that the payment is purely voluntary and will be treated as a gift to the U.S. Treasury. If the taxpayer’s intentions cannot be ascertained, return the payment to the taxpayer. Proceeds from the sale of assets seized prior to the expiration of the statute can be applied after the date of expiration. The affected modules require Transaction Code (TC)
Closing Code (cc)
be input. Any outstanding balance will be closed using TC
cc
after the application of sale proceeds and after the statute expires. Proceeds received as a result of a levy that was served prior to the CSED be applied to the expired module(s).

“When a case/module is received with a short CSED (less than six months remaining on the CSED) which has been erroneously assigned, it may be ap

Note: Managers should see IRM 1.4.50.9.1.1, Shelving Erroneously Assigned Cases/Modules.

With situation speciﬁc guidance from Headquarters, managers may close imminent statute cases or modules issued to their hold ﬁles with less than six months on the CSED by routing certain cases or modules to an ICS/Entity Quality Analyst (IQA) for CNC closing. This temporary limited use of the Trans- action Code
with Closing Code

, requires Headquarters guidance. such guidance is issued, it will list the case criteria and speciﬁc actions required and will be referred to in the ICS case history by the group manager. An erroneously assigned case is one that is delivered inadvertently. A case is not considered erroneously assigned solely because it was delivered to the Group Designation Hold File with less than six months on the CSED on one or more modules.
Example: Imminent CSED modules intended for an ACS project are inadvertently routed to GM hold ﬁles.
Example: A system conversion leads to the erroneous assignment of CSED cases to GM hold ﬁles.
Programming errors result in the assignment of low risk imminent CSED cases to GM hold ﬁles.
Example: A case/module is not considered erroneously assigned when a case is transferred from ACS where the taxpayer needs contact. These cases bear Priority 100, and Sub Code 601, 602, 603, or 604.

5.1.19.5.2 (04-26-2018) Working Imminent CSEDs
Field Collecting (

) Imminent CSED accounts sometimes include modules that do not have imminent CSEDs. It is important that all modules are worked appropriately. However, low dollar imminent CSED accounts should not receive undue or excessive attention simply because the collection statute is imminent. (

) Cases should not be closed with an inappropriate Currently Not Collectible (CNC) closing code merely because an imminent CSED is about to expire one or more modules. If an investigation has been completed prior to the ration that shows the account to be truly uncollectible, based on the facts of the case, all modules should be reported as such under the appropriate closing code as directed in IRM
, Currently Not Collectible. (

) Upon receipt of an imminent CSED module, or when CSED(s) become imminent, discuss with your group manager the imminent CSED(s) during Imminent ﬁrst Collection Consultation (CC) following receipt. Discuss and agree on the most appropriate plan of action based on the facts of the case. (

) The group manager will document the initial plan of action in the case during the CC. In subsequent CCs or as facts warrant, the RO will keep the group manager advised of the progress of all imminent CSED modules. (
) If a case is received with

days or less left on the CSED, without delay make an immediate appointment with your group manager. The RO and manager will discuss the case as an ad hoc CC, and the GM will document the initial plan of action in the case history during the ad hoc CC. (
